title: 104_hr2727
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" aims to ensure that Federal regulations are only enacted by Congress, as outlined in Article I of the United States Constitution. This Act prohibits the delegation of regulatory authority to unelected officials and requires all agency regulations to be approved by Congress before taking effect, promoting accountability and democracy in the legislative process. SEC. 3. ENACTMENT OF AGENCY REGULATIONS.

Regulations cannot take effect before Congress enacts a bill containing the regulation's text. Agencies must submit a report to Congress explaining the proposed regulation.

SEC. 4. EXPEDITED CONGRESSIONAL PROCEDURES FOR AGENCY REGULATIONS. (a) Introduction.--Within three legislative days of an agency submitting a report under section 3(b), the Majority Leader of each House of Congress must introduce a bill containing the regulation's text. If not done, any Member of that House may introduce the bill.
(b) Bill.--A bill under this section refers to a bill in Congress that approves agency regulations, giving them the force of law.
(c) Referral and Consideration.--Such bills do not need to be referred to a committee, and any Member can move for consideration. (c) Referral and Consideration.--A bill described in subsection (b) bypasses committee referral. Any Member can move for consideration of the bill, with waived points of order. The motion is privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. If agreed to, the respective House proceeds to consider the bill. The bill shall be immediately considered without interruption once a motion to proceed is agreed upon. Debate is limited to one hour, with equal time for supporters and opponents. Amendments, motions to limit debate, postpone, consider other business, or recommit the bill are not allowed. Reconsideration of the bill's vote is also not permitted. The bill must be considered without interruption once a motion to proceed is agreed upon. Debate is limited to one hour, with equal time for supporters and opponents. Amendments, motions to limit debate, postpone, consider other business, or recommit the bill are not allowed. Reconsideration of the bill's vote is also not permitted. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on regulations shall be decided without debate. Final passage of the bill must occur within 60 days of introduction. A motion to suspend certain procedures can be passed with a majority vote. If the other House has acted, specific procedures apply. Upon passage of a motion, the bill will be treated like other bills. If the other House has passed a bill with the same text, it will not be referred to a committee and will only be considered for final passage. The House receiving the bill will follow normal procedures but will vote on the bill from the other House for final passage. Upon receipt of a bill from the other House, final passage will be based on the bill from the other House. After the bill from the other House is dealt with, the original bill will not be considered. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "agency" and "regulation" in accordance with existing laws. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to agency regulations made after its enactment. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Regulations in bills under this Act are not subject to judicial review as agency actions.
